12.16.text: The decorative use of wire in southern Africa

20.16.text: and a whole new material, in the form of telephone wire.

24.16.text: Rural to urban migration meant that newfound industrial materials

29.16.text: started to replace hard-to-come-by natural grasses.

33.16.text: So, here you can see the change

35.16.text: from use -- starting to use contemporary materials.

37.16.text: These pieces date back from the '40s to the late '50s.

42.16.text: In the '90s, my interest and passion for transitional art forms

46.16.text: led me to a new form,

48.16.text: which came from a squatter camp outside Durban.

50.16.text: And I got the opportunity to start working with this community

54.16.text: at that point, and started developing, really,

57.16.text: and mentoring them in terms of scale, in terms of the design.

63.16.text: And the project soon grew from five to 50 weavers in about a year.

67.16.text: Soon we had outgrown the scrap yards, what they could provide,

71.16.text: so we coerced a wire manufacturer to help us,

74.16.text: and not only to supply the materials on bobbins,

77.16.text: but to produce to our color specifications.

80.16.text: At the same time, I was thinking, well,

82.16.text: there's lots of possibility here to produce contemporary products,

86.16.text: away from the ethnic, a little bit more contemporary.

90.16.text: So I developed a whole range around -- mass-produced range --

93.16.text: that obviously fitted into a much higher-end decor market

97.16.text: that could be exported and also service our local market.

101.16.text: We started experimenting, as you can see, in terms of shapes,

105.16.text: forms. The scale became very important,

109.16.text: and it's become our pet project. It's successful,

113.16.text: it's been running for 12 years. And we supply the Conran shops,

117.16.text: and Donna Karan, and so it's kind of great.

120.16.text: This is our group, our main group of weavers.

123.16.text: They come on a weekly basis to Durban.

127.16.text: They've all moved back to the rural area where they came from.

129.16.text: It's a weekly turnaround of production.

131.16.text: This is the community that I originally showed you the slide of.

137.16.text: and it's supporting work for 300 weavers.

141.16.text: And the rest says it all.
